title: What are my options beside bankruptcy?
question: I filed a BK, discharged only 18 months ago. Due to Covid and a very messy, drawn out divorce, Iâ€™ve had to live off of credit cards. I am no longer in a position to pay those monthly bills. What other options do I have?
answers: Discuss with an attorney why you even would need to file.i.e. assets protected? And 48 months after filing ch 7 you can file a ch 13 too. Good luck.

When you say you filed bankruptcy recently, I assume it was a chapter 7. If so, then you can't commence another chapter 7 for eight years. In some situations people will file a chapter 13 after a chapter 7, but to get a discharge you would have to wait for 4 years after your chapter 7 filing, otherwise your unsecured debts, the credit cards, won't be discharged.

If you aren't able to file bankruptcy, then you may try to contact each creditor, explain your situation, and then see if they will give you a forbearance, put you on a hardship status, or agree to take a lesser payment.

Also, you may try to contact each creditor and see if they will accept a lesser amount than what you owe. However, this does require funds to give them for a settlement and you run the risk that they may issue you a 1099-C for the portion of the debt they are cancelling which could result in a tax liability issue for you.

If you are on a "fixed income" like social security and you don't have major assets, then you may be what they call judgement proof. This means if a creditor comes at you they won't be able to levy your income and there are no assets to take. Yet, the creditors will most likely keep calling you and sending you letters asking you to pay.
I agree with attorney Granvold. At this stage, you should make sure your assets are protected and wait, if at all, to file a bankruptcy.
Best to consult with a local bankruptcy attorney to determine options.

I agree with all my colleagues in what they have stated. I would also add that even though you are probably not yet eligible for another bankruptcy discharge, it may be worth discussing with an experienced bankruptcy lawyer whether filing a no discharge chapter 13 might be in order if you truly require protection from creditors at this time.

I suggest you meet with an attorney to look at whether you have assets that a creditor could take if it sues you to collect. You might be "judgment proof" and not have to worry about anything other than annoying calls from debt collectors. More info at the link below. Hope this perspective helps!

https://www.avvo.com/legal-guides/ugc/why-you-don-t-need-to-file-bankruptcy
My colleagues have asked you the right questions and given you good advice. More facts are needed to go beyond what they have advised.
